p: P. nigrum, or black pepper, is native in Kerala in Southwestern India and widely distributed in tropical regions, including Indonesia. Its fruits are usually dried and used for spices and seasonings. This plant is used as a folk medicine to treat gastrointestinal disorder, rheumatic, flu, colds, muscular aches, and fever diseases [ 12]. Biological activities of P. nigrum EO have been known as insecticidal [ 18, 19], larvicidal [ 20], antioxidant [ 12], and antimicrobial activities [ 21]. Caryophyllene and limonene have been reported as the dominant compounds of P. nigrum EO [ 22]. For antihyperuricemia, ethanol, water, and methanol extracts of P. nigrum, and piperine, have been known to be active substances against xanthine oxidase [ 23, 24, 25]. However, the inhibitory effect of essential oil of this plant on xanthine oxidase to the best of our knowledge is still unknown.
